title: Added fix so that staging data still gets cleaned up even if collectOutput fails
body:
The problem is that line 367 of AbstractJobLauncher.addWorkUnit() adds each WorkUnit from Source.getWorkUnits() to the jobState.taskStates Map. So the Map contains all the pre-runtime values of the WorkUnits. However, on line 308 of Fork.buildWriter(), the value of ConfigurationKeys.WRITER_FILE_PATH is set if it is not currently present in the WorkUnit. Fork.buildWriter() is only called during the runtime of each WorkUnit. So the value of ConfigurationKeys.WRITER_FILE_PATH never makes it into the JobState object. So, the JobLauncherUtils.cleanStagingData() method won’t do anything, as the WorkUnit it is looking at doesn’t have a value for  ConfigurationKeys.WRITER_FILE_PATH.

This pull request will ensure this doesn't happen again. If the WRITER_FILE_PATH does not exist in the config during cleanup, the code uses its default value to cleanup the data.

title: Allow schema or data record to be Copyable even if it is not going to multiple branches
body:
Currently Gobblin assumes that if a schema or data record is not going into more than one fork branch, then it is not an instance of Copyable. However, it is still possible for the last converter before the ForkOperator to return Copyable schema or data records. If this is the case, Gobblin should still call Copyable.copy() to get a copy of the schema or data record.

Signed-off-by: Yinan Li liyinan926@gmail.com

title: Fixed a bug that caused an empty list of previous WorkUnitStates to pass into SourceState
body:
In pull request #65, a new Constructor is added to SourceState that takes a previous SourceState and calls SourceState.getPreviousWorkUnitStates() to populate the SourceState.previousTaskStates. However, it turns out previousTaskStates is always empty and therefore the empty list gets passed into the current SourceState. This is the root cause for the issue with gobblin-stand-alone.

Signed-off-by: Yinan Li liyinan926@gmail.com

repo.name: gobblin
repo.description: A distributed data integration framework that simplifies common aspects of big data integration such as data ingestion, replication, organization and lifecycle management for both streaming and batch data ecosystems.

title: Allow Writers, Converters, and QualityCheckers to read the same config key from different branches
body:
These changes allow custom converters, writer, or quality checkers to read the same config key from different branches. For example, if a Fork Operator creates two branches, and each branch requires using the same converter.

An example would be as follows:

fork.branches=2
fork.operator=gobblin.fork.IdentityForkOperator

converter.classes.0=gobblin.converter.MyConverter1
converter.classes.1=gobblin.converter.MyConverter1

converter.myconverter1.config.0=configValueForBranch0
converter.myconverter1.config.1=configValueForBranch1

Where MyConverter1 executes the method "ForkOperatorUtils.getPropertyNameForBranch(workunit, ConfigurationKeys.CONVERTER_MYCONVERTER1_CONFIG)" and "ConfigurationKeys.CONVERTER_MYCONVERTER1_CONFIG=converter.myconverter1.config"

repo.name: gobblin
repo.description: A distributed data integration framework that simplifies common aspects of big data integration such as data ingestion, replication, organization and lifecycle management for both streaming and batch data ecosystems.

title: Fixing FindBugs warnings
body:
FindBugs Warnings:

1:

gobblin.source.workunit.MultiWorkUnitWeightedQueue$WeightedMultiWorkUnit defines compareTo(MultiWorkUnitWeightedQueue$WeightedMultiWorkUnit) and uses Object.equals()

This class defines a compareTo(...) method but inherits its equals() method from java.lang.Object. Generally, the value of compareTo should return zero if and only if equals returns true. If this is violated, weird and unpredictable failures will occur in classes such as PriorityQueue. In Java 5 the PriorityQueue.remove method uses the compareTo method, while in Java 6 it uses the equals method.

From the JavaDoc for the compareTo method in the Comparable interface:

```
It is strongly recommended, but not strictly required that (x.compareTo(y)==0) == (x.equals(y)). Generally speaking, any class that implements the Comparable interface and violates this condition should clearly indicate this fact. The recommended language is "Note: this class has a natural ordering that is inconsistent with equals." 
```

2:

Should gobblin.source.workunit.MultiWorkUnitWeightedQueue$WeightedMultiWorkUnit be a _static_ inner class?

This class is an inner class, but does not use its embedded reference to the object which created it.  This reference makes the instances of the class larger, and may keep the reference to the creator object alive longer than necessary.  If possible, the class should be made static.

Gobblin currently serializes both the job state and task states of each job run to the state store. Since the job state of a job run contains the task states, there's really no need to serialize the task states.

This pull request adds a series of Converters and a Source class.

Converters:

ObjectToStringConverter.java - converts an Object to its String representation
StringFilterConverter.java - filters out an inputRecord based on whether or not it matches a regex
StringSplitterConverter.java - splits a string based on some configurable value

Source:

DatePartitionedSource.java - implementation of the Source interface that reads data from a date-partitioned directory
MultiWorkUnitWeightedQueue.java - users a PriorityQueue to pair WorkUnits together based on some weight

title: Fixing Bugs in MultiConverter
body:
There were some bugs in the class that caused converters which conditionally returned varying types of Iterables to not work. For example, if a converter conditionally returned either a EmptyIterable or a SingleRecordIterable, the MultiConverter would not fully iterate through all the records. The new implementation takes into account these scenarios, and there have been more tests added to the test class to check for this behavior.

The biggest change in design, is that when iterating through the stack of converters to process, if a converter returns an EmptyIterable, then the code should move to the next record returned by the previous converter, rather than quitting.

title: Fix query for multiple delta fields in case of simple watermark
body:
When `source.querybased.watermark.type=simple` and `extract.delta.fields` contains a comma separated list of fields (e.g: id, type), one of the initial MySQL query looks like this during the job initialization:

`SELECT max(COALESCE(id,type)) FROM test  where  (id,type >= 477 and id,type <= 544);`

The query syntax seems to be invalid which leads to the following error:
`java.sql.SQLException: Operand should contain 1 column(s)`

After checking the generated queries of other watermark types, I suspect that here the fields in the where clause should be coalesced too (e.g: COALESCE(id,type) >=477...etc)
If this is the case (and the where clause is not intended to be a row subquery for instance) then the patch would address this issue.

repo.name: gobblin
repo.description: A distributed data integration framework that simplifies common aspects of big data integration such as data ingestion, replication, organization and lifecycle management for both streaming and batch data ecosystems.

title: Run forks asynchronously as Runnables in a thread pool
body:
This is the first working version. I created this for the upcoming design review. Please take a look if you get a chance before the design review meeting. A brief description of the design is as follows:

The basic idea is each fork maintains a bounded blocking queue for buffering records put by the parent task. The parent task is the producer and the fork is the consumer. The task puts new records into the queue of each fork and each fork keeps getting records off its queue until all records get processed. The queue is backed by a `LinkedBlockingDeque` and in additional to normal queue operations, it also keeps track of the following statistics for monitoring purpose:
- Queue size
- Queue fill ratio (queue size/queue capacity)
- Put attempt count
- Mean rate of put attempts (puts/sec)
- Get attempt count
- Mean rate of get attempts (gets/sec)

The queue is bounded so it won't grow indefinitely. Both puts and gets are blocked with a configurable timeout. Having the puts and gets to timeout prevents the producer and consumer from being blocked indefinitely. Since the fork doesn't know how many records will be put into the queue in advance and an empty queue necessarily doesn't mean the parent task is done (it may just be because the extractor is slow), the fork has a boolean flag `parentTaskDone` that is set by the parent task once it is done (either succeeded or failed). The contract is that the fork should not expect any new incoming records into the queue once `parentTaskDone` is set to `true`. This flag is guaranteed to be set by the parent task even if the task fails.

When putting a new record, the task has to make sure the record gets put into the queue of each of its forks. If the forks are slow, the puts may timeout and need to be retried in the next iteration until all puts for the current record succeed, at which point the task can move to the next record. 

Each fork also maintain a `ForkState` that tells the current state of the fork. The fork will reject any attempt from the parent task to put new records into the queue if the current state is `ForkState.FAILED` so the parent task is informed. This is necessary in case the fork fails for some reason and the task has no knowledge about the failure and keeps putting new records into the queue. 

The parent task upon completion of all its forks will check if each fork has succeeded (having state `ForkState.SUCCEEDED`) and throws an exception to fail itself if any of its forks failed.

The forks of a task run in a separate thread pool managed by the task executor. The reason why forks run in a separate thread pool other than the one for running tasks is this avoids an additional race relationship between a task and its forks (in additional to the already existing race against the queue). This is a custom `ThreadPoolExecutor` with a core thread pool size equal to that of the thread pool for running tasks. The reason is there's always at least one fork per task. The thread pool is also essentially unbounded by setting the max thread pool size to `Integer.MAX_VALUE`. This is to make sure all forks of a task get a thread to run so all forks of the task are making progress. This is necessary since otherwise the parent task will be blocked if the record queue (bounded) of some fork is full and that fork has not yet started to run because of no available thread. The task cannot proceed in this case because it has to make sure every records go to every forks. The work queue of the thread pool executor is a `SynchronousQueue`. This essentially forces new threads to be created if there are more forks to run than the core thread pool size.

This pull request also include some additional enhancements to the `ExecutorsUtils` class.
- `ExecutorsUtils` now uses `ThreadFactoryBuilder` to create `ThreadFactory`.
- `ExecutorsUtils` has a variant of the `newThreadFactory`  that allows specifying a thread naming format.
- The new `newThreadFactory` method is used to add custom thread naming format.

body:
The solution is not to use Hadoop's MultiThreadedMapper, but instead overwriting the Mapper.run() method to run the WorkUnits in the TaskExecutor. Now the map() method is only responsible for de-serializing and collecting WorkUnits, but not running them.

title: Fixed the job configuration file monitor
body:
This commit contains the following fixes:
1. When a new job configuration file is added or an existing file is changed, the file is reloaded with properties included from .properties file in the same directory and .properties files in ancestor directories. Then the job is scheduled/rescheduled.
2. When an existing .properties file is changed, all job configuration files affected will be reloaded and rescheduled, again with properties included from the .properties file and .properties files in ancestor directories. The affected job configuration files include those in the same directory and the ones under the subdirectories (recursively). 
3. Code refactoring.

Signed-off-by: Yinan Li liyinan926@gmail.com

title: Fix Mapreduce startup (based on pull request #36)
body:
I've incorporated the requirements discussed in #36. Handling of the command line parameters has been changed accordingly:

$GOBBLIN_HOME/build.gradle:
- bump avro version to 1.7.6 to conform with the version of avro-mapred
- force guava version 15.0: otherwise during the build gradle may pick up guava 17.0 and will include it in  
  the /lib directory
  instead of the defined version 15.0. (This may lead to issues like
  IllegalAccessError: tried to access method com.google.common.base.Stopwatch.<init>()V from class 
  org.apache.hadoop.mapreduce.lib.input.FileInputFormat)

$GOBBLIN_HOME/conf/gobblin-env.sh:
- A script to initialize environment variables called by gobblin-standalone.sh and gobblin-mapreduce.sh

$GOBBLIN_HOME/bin/gobblin-mapreduce.sh:
- Job configuration as command line parameter
- JobTracker/ResourceManager and FileSystem arguments became optional
- Accepts multiple job jars as command line arguments
- $GOBBLIN_WORK_DIR can be overridden by the --workdir parameter

$GOBBLIN_HOME/bin/gobblin-standalone.sh:
- Job configuration as command line parameter
- Accepts multiple job jars as command line arguments
- $GOBBLIN_WORK_DIR can be overridden by the --workdir parameter

$GOBBLIN_HOME/gobblin-runtime/src/main/java/gobblin/runtime/mapreduce/CliMRJobLauncher.java :
- Use GenericOptionsParser to be able to pick up Gobblin as well as Hadoop related command line  
  arguments

Others:
- Removed internal LinkedIn dependencies from LIBJARS
- Missing command line toggles (sysconfig and jobconfig)added
- Load Gobblin related dependencies first to HADOOP_CLASSPATH to avoid jar hell

title: Make reporting task-level counters as Hadoop counters optional
body:
Since Hadoop imposes a system-level limit (default to 120) on the number of counters, a Gobblin MR job may easily go beyond that limit if the job has a large number of tasks and each task has a few counters. This commit makes it optional to report task-level counters as Hadoop counters. 

Signed-off-by: Yinan Li liyinan926@gmail.com

title: Fix mapreduce startup
body:
Hi,

Great to see that Gobblin is released, many thanks for open-sourcing it!
During the evaluation of the MR mode I've found some minor issues in the start script which I'd
like to fix with this patch. The changes are as follows:

gobblin-mapreduce.sh :
- Added a new command line parameter: <job jar>
- Removed internal Linkedin dependencies from LIBJARS
- Load Gobblin related dependencies first to HADOOP_CLASSPATH to avoid jar hell
- Introduce gobblin-env.sh
- Add missing command line toggles (sysconfig and jobconfig)

CliMRJobLauncher.java :
- Use GenericOptionsParser to be able to pick up Gobblin as well as Hadoop related 
  command line arguments

gobblin-env.sh
- A script that initializes environment variables used by gobblin-standalone.sh 
  and gobblin-mapreduce.sh

build.gradle:
- bump avro version to 1.7.6 to conform with the version of avro-mapred
- force guava version 15.0: otherwise during the build gradle may pick up guava 17.0 
  and will include that one in the /lib directory instead of the defined version 15.0. 

Thanks,
Lorand

repo.name: gobblin

title: Moving log4j-extras dependency to scheduler
body: Repos dependent on gobblin and the gobblin stand alone scripts are failing because log4jextras is needed as a runtime dependency, but is only expressed as a runtime dependency in gobblin-distribution, which most downstream repos are not dependent on. I add the dependency to scheduler, which is where is belongs.

repo.name: gobblin
repo.description: A distributed data integration framework that simplifies common aspects of big data integration such as data ingestion, replication, organization and lifecycle management for both streaming and batch data ecosystems.

title: Make each forked branch have its own built-in task-level metrics
body:
Currently, built-in task-level metrics are shared among the forked branches of each task. This is causing metric mismatch issues. This commit fixes the issues by making each forked branch of a task have its own copies of built-in task-level metrics that have the branch index in the metric name.

Signed-off-by: Yinan Li liyinan926@gmail.com

repo.name: gobblin
repo.description: A distributed data integration framework that simplifies common aspects of big data integration such as data ingestion, replication, organization and lifecycle management for both streaming and batch data ecosystems.

title: Do not throw and IOException when a given state store already exists
body:
Currently FsStateStore throws an IOException if a given state store already exists while treating to create the store directory. The right behavior should be to do an no-op and return if the store directory already exists. This commit fixes it.

Signed-off-by: Yinan Li liyinan926@gmail.com

repo.name: gobblin
repo.description: A distributed data integration framework that simplifies common aspects of big data integration such as data ingestion, replication, organization and lifecycle management for both streaming and batch data ecosystems.

title: add log4jextras runtime dependency
body:
Change log4jextras to runtime as log4j internally depends on additional features provided by the library. 
BTW, gradle runtime dependency extends compile dependency. That's why it was working before.

body:

2. Modify build script to accommodate gobblin-compaction.
   There are two dependencies (jpox-core-1.2.2.jar, jpox-rdbms-1.2.2.jar) that are needed by Hive embedded server, but don't seem to exist in a remote repo. So I included them in the commit. (gobblin-compaction/lib)
   gradlew clean build passed.

title: Report all metric counters as Hadoop counters in MR mode
body:
Currently only the four built-in counters (records and bytes at the job- and task-level) are reported as Hadoop counters. Since tracking-purger will be having its own custom counters soon, those counters should also be reported as Hadoop counters so they can be collected upon job completion.

Signed-off-by: Yinan Li liyinan926@gmail.com

title: Added a LoggingUncaughtExceptionHandler and used it in all thread pools
body:
The LoggingUncaughtExceptionHandler logs uncaught exceptions using a SLF4J logger and is used as the default UncaughtExceptionHandler. This commit also added more unit tests for some classes under the utility module.

Signed-off-by: Yinan Li liyinan926@gmail.com

repo.name: gobblin
repo.description: A distributed data integration framework that simplifies common aspects of big data integration such as data ingestion, replication, organization and lifecycle management for both streaming and batch data ecosystems.

title: Assign a multi-task ID to each MultiWorkUnit
body:
Currently MultiWorkUnits do not have a task ID assigned to them. When the MRJobLauncher serializes a WorkUnit/MultiWorkUnit to a file, it uses the task ID assigned to the WorkUnit/MultiWorkUnit as the file name. Because a MultiWorkUnit does not have a task ID assigned to it, the file it gets serialized into does not have a proper file name. This commit fixes this by giving a MultiWorkUnit a so-called multi-task ID.

Signed-off-by: Yinan Li liyinan926@gmail.com

repo.name: gobblin
repo.description: A distributed data integration framework that simplifies common aspects of big data integration such as data ingestion, replication, organization and lifecycle management for both streaming and batch data ecosystems.

title: Restructuring Folder Layout and Fixing OOM Issue in MRJobLauncher
body:
I re-structured all the projects according to ETL-2505. The source, writer, converter, qualitychecker, common-api folders are all gone. The new folders are: 

'api','azkaban','core','distribution','example','metrics','metastore','rest-service','runtime','scheduler','test','utility'

The build passes, and I tested the new version on the data-purger and the job worked. Merging this change will break the product-spec of any downstream dependent products, so those need to be done right after the merge has been done.

title: Throw an exception if it fails to load a specified ForkOperator class
body:
The current code silently returns a null if it fails to load the class. It should throw an exception in this case.

Signed-off-by: Yinan Li liyinan926@gmail.com

repo.name: gobblin
repo.description: A distributed data integration framework that simplifies common aspects of big data integration such as data ingestion, replication, organization and lifecycle management for both streaming and batch data ecosystems.

title: Added a tool for state store migration
body:
Due to the package renaming, the package names of TaskState and JobState changed. Because the current state store uses SequenceFiles that store the fully-qualified class names of the key and value classes in the metafile, Gobblin won't be able to read the state store using the new TaskState and JobState classes unless we migrate the state store to use the new classes. This commit adds a utility for doing the migration.

Signed-off-by: Yinan Li liyinan926@gmail.com

This commit renames all packages to use the new naming convention that starts with "gobblin.". It also replaces all occurrences of 'uif' with 'gobblin' (case insensitive). 

Jira: ETL-2476

Signed-off-by: Yinan Li liyinan926@gmail.com
